titleStmt.title: meeting of project group discussing two past project events

publicationStmt.publisher: Barbara Seidlhofer, Stefan Majewski, Ruth Osimk, Marie-Luise Pitzl
publicationStmt.distributor: VOICE Project, University of Vienna, Austria

availability.p: The Vienna-Oxford International Corpus of English (VOICE) was created by Barbara Seidlhofer (project director) and Angelika Breiteneder, Theresa Klimpfinger, Stefan Majewski, Marie-Luise Pitzl (project researchers). Minor revisions and corrections were made by Ruth Osimk. VOICE 1.1 XML is available for download at the VOICE Project's website http://www.univie.ac.at/voice/ under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported (CC BY-NC-SA 3.0) License (http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-sa/3.0/). The original audio files are held at the Department of English, University of Vienna. 23 selected audio files are available as audio streams in the VOICE Online interface at the VOICE Project's website http://www.univie.ac.at/voice.
The recommended citation for VOICE 1.1 XML is:

p.bibl: VOICE. 2011. The Vienna-Oxford International Corpus of English (version 1.1 XML). Director: Barbara Seidlhofer; Researchers: Angelika Breiteneder, Theresa Klimpfinger, Stefan Majewski, Ruth Osimk, Marie-Luise Pitzl.

availability.p: The short citation for VOICE 1.1 XML is:

p.bibl: VOICE. 2011. The Vienna-Oxford International Corpus of English (version 1.1 XML).

availability.p: For further information about availability and copyright permissions, please see the README file included in the download package. For further enquiries please contact the VOICE Project at voice@univie.ac.at.

notesStmt.note: This meeting takes place at the university language center and involves eleven speakers who work at different language schools in Europe. They meet in order to discuss the success of, and problems encountered with, their individual projects. S4 and later on S5 share their experience and related the details of their individual project events in their countries to the group. The other speakers react, ask question and all speakers join in the discussion. S1 is the chair of the meeting, yet S2 also very actively steers the discussion. At the end of the meeting, S8 gives the other speakers instructions how to get to a venue in the evening.

equipment.p: Portable minidisc recorder with electret condenser stereo microphone

namespace.name: http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0
namespace.tagUsage: Used to mark a stretch of speech commonly preceded and followed by a pause or by a change of speaker. A u is, however, not required to be bounded by a pause or a change of speaker, nor does it represent a turn in a conversation analytic sense. At a minimum, a u is some phonetic production or noise made by a given speaker or a group of speakers.
Used to mark a pause either between or within utterances. Used without dur attribute to indicate a brief pause up to half a second.

Used with different type attributes to mark:
typeoverlap
overlaps typeonomatopoeia
onomatopoeic sounds typeipa
transcriptions in the international phonetic alphabet

Used to mark laughter and other speaker noises and non-verbal feedback.
speaker_noise
coughing
nods
shakes head
smacks lips
sniffs
swallows
whistles
wordlike
laughing
Used to mark speech which is stressed or emphasized in a way that goes beyond regular nuclear stress.

Used to mark lengthening of sounds and intonation (fall, rise). The following type attributes are used to mark:
lengthening
lengthened sounds intonation
a significant change in intonation, marked with the following function attribute for:
fall
falling intonation rise
rising intonation
Intonation may or may not coincide with syntactic boundaries.

Used to mark the point at which some paralinguistic feature changes. The following attribute values are used to mark:
voice
voice quality
imitating
laugh
neutral
phone
reading
reading_aloud
sigh
singing
whisp
yawning
tempo
speed of utterance
a
accelerando l
lento neutral
neutral
loud
loudness
f
neutral
p
Used to mark contextual information relevant to the understanding of the interaction or the interaction as such. The voice:desc attribute provides a short prose description of the contextual event.

Used to mark text supplied by the transcriber because the original is unintelligible or needed to be anonymized. The reason attribute is used to mark:
unintelligible
unintelligible speech anonymization
anonymized speech

Used to mark other-continuation, i.e. whenever a speaker continues another speaker's u without a pause. Other-continuation is to be interpreted temporally and does not relate to form or content of the speakers' utterances.
Used to mark speech which cannot be transcribed with certainty, because it is difficult to hear or understand for the transcriber.

Used to mark a word or phrase as belonging to some language other than English. The following values for the type attribute are used to mark:
L1
the speaker's first language LN
a language other than the speaker's first language LQ
a language where it cannot be ascertained whether it is the speaker's first or other language.
Whenever possible, the voice:translation attribute provides a rough translation of the non-English speech into English.
Used with the type attribute set to spelt to mark words or word fragments which are spelt out, i.e. words whose constituents are pronounced as individual letters.

namespace.name: http://www.univie.ac.at/voice/ns/1.0
namespace.tagUsage: Used to mark the beginning of a new audio track used in transcription (usually three minutes in length) and thus refers to the audio recording of the transcribed speech event.
Used to mark speech directed towards a particular speaker. The whowho attribute indicates the addressed speaker.

Used to mark a pronunciation variation or coinage as described in the VOICE mark-up conventions [2.1].the VOICE mark-up conventions [2.1]. An existing word corresponding to the PVC may be provided within a commentcomment attribute within the voice:pvcvoice:pvc element. Additional phonetic transcription may be provided within a voice:ipavoice:ipa attribute within the voice:pvcvoice:pvc element.

Vienna

person.occupation: language teacher, coordinator of university department
